instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.SMC_BATLOW_L: What is SMC_BATLOW_L? SMC_BATLOW_L refers to a power management signal that indicates a low battery condition. The "_L" suffix suggests that this is an active-low signal, meaning that it becomes low when the battery reaches a low voltage threshold..
definitions.P5VS0_EN: What is P5VS0_EN? This signal enables the PP5V_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P3V3S0_EN: What is P3V3S0_EN? This signal enables the PP3V3_S0 power rail when it is high. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.P5VS5_EN: What is P5VS5_EN? P5VS5_EN is a signal that turns on the PP5V_S5 power rail. Signals with _EN on the end enable whatever came before the _EN if the signal is high. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMCâ€™s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.WS_KBD_ONOFF_L: What is WS_KBD_ONOFF_L? WS_KBD_ONOFF_L is a signal that comes from the keyboard that tells the SMC that the power button has been pressed.  L means whatever before the L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. This signal directly affects SMC_ONOFF_L.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
Small Water damage

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>: 12.57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.405V
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.343V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>: 5.053V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>: 5.053V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>: 3.343V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL>: 5.054V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL>: 3.343V

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>: 5.054V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>: 3.346V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>: 3.342V

PP1V5R1V35_S3: 1.354V

No S0 State 
No SMC Bypass mode

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>: 2.327V
diode mode with red probe to gnd:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>: 0.088V shorted ????

Any suggestion before I'll pass it i the UC?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
After UC Cleaning Still the same situation:

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>: 2.318V
diode mode with red probe to gnd:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>: 0.088V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
088 is to low for that signal.
Check first <RESISTOR>R1924</RESISTOR> for corrosion.
Test disconnecting RIO flex and also clean J4410.
Remove <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> and test again; also remove <CHIP>U2800</CHIP>.
Finally remains PCH and SMC; put good flux and reflow them, if needed.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> resistance to gnd: 2.8 Ohms
If <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> is removed <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> mesures 3.4V

Tracked all <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> rails and removed and mesured all resistances (<RESISTOR>R7981</RESISTOR> , <RESISTOR>R7985</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7986</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7987</RESISTOR>, <RESISTOR>R7988</RESISTOR> ) to make sure no short to gnd
Then checked and removed all components after those rails that may be shorted to gnd: <SIGNAL>P5VS0_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>P3V3S0_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PBUSVSENS_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>TBT_S0_EN</SIGNAL>.

Regarding <SIGNAL>TBT_S0_EN</SIGNAL> it appeared that when I removed <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>, the resistance to gnd of <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> (pin 17@ <CHIP>U9410</CHIP>) mesured 45KOhms vs 2.8 Ohms[FONT="Calibri"] and in diode mode with red probe to gnd <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is 0.486V  VS  0.088V before,  [/FONT]which is a very good thing but when I've put the board under power I lost the <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> rail.
Question: what is the relation between <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> ( Thunderbolt ) and <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> ( normally NONE).
Put back <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> still no <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>
Tracked it back and find out that <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> (<SIGNAL>P5VS5_EN</SIGNAL> ) is missing and <RESISTOR>R5098</RESISTOR> is OK.
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 0V

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> : 3.297V
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> : 3.372V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>: 3.371
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> : 3.400V
<SIGNAL>SMC_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>: 0V
I have 12Mhz at Y5010
At <CHIP>U2600</CHIP>:
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>: 3.402V
Pin 12: 32khz is OK

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
BIG Sorry
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 0V I was mesuring <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL> because of OPENBOARD View pointing me at it......

which means NO S5 State at all

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
I've reflowed the SMC and now Ihave the S5 state back :p
also with <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> removed , [FONT="Calibri"]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> is 3.331V ;)[/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
replaced also <RESISTOR>R7978</RESISTOR> because I've lost it.
Machine fixed: Fans spins
So the issue was <CHIP>U9410</CHIP> "shorting" [FONT=Calibri]<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_R_L</SIGNAL> [/FONT]rail to gnd.
Don't think I'll put a new <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>, I will leave it without it which means no thunderbolt port A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
I'm back with that board:
After I've put it back in the mbp, I had no bcklight ( fixed) and once ON it doesn't power OFF.
Tried to short the debug power pads ( <RESISTOR>R5015</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R5016</RESISTOR> ) still the same also with the keyboard connected I've pressed the power buton and mesured <SIGNAL>WS_KBD_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>: this one passes from 3.397V to 0V which means the keyboard is OK.
I'm suspecting the SMC as if you read higher in the post I had to reflow it to recover the S5 state.
Any suggestion before I attempt a risky reflow again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message: Always reball SMC if it reacts to reflow...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
Ola 2Informaticos,
I've reballed the SMC, and it's still the same situation like before:
Marchine turning ON, fans slowly runs to max speed, and no way to turn it OFF by shorting the power pads or from the keyboard.

So I've attempted a reflow again and the machine is acting the same except now I'm mesuring 0.367V VS 3.372V at the power pads (<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>) .

I think the SMC is bad........What do you think?
Is there's something else I can check?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
Is better to test other SMC, just in case.
Then come back and report...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
I did a Last reflow at 500Â°C and 120L/m and apparently it's working properly now : recovered 3,3v at <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and turning off when shorting power pads.
I left it on my desktop and will re assemble it later.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
Probably SMC wasn't properly soldered on the board after reball...
Be sure to always use leaded solder.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
re assemble everything and still the same problem, except that its reseting the SMC when shorting ( just a short contact not 5 sec )  the debupg power pads and not turning off.
When I press on the power botton of the keyboard it goes from 3.3V to 0.5V not less.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>   No S0     <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>  is Low   ( shorted?????)
threads.message:
Start disconnecting perypherics from the logic board.
See when/if board starts to work correct again...
